Award.AwardTitle: Near-Surface Conversions of Semi-Diurnal Internal Tide Beam Energy
Award.AbstractNarration:
As the gravitationally-forced tides flow over topography they disturb the ocean's internal stratification (e.g., layers of warm over cold water), creating internal oscillations (internal tides) with relatively strong currents and short spatial scales. The energy of the internal tides plays an important role in mixing the deep ocean with subsequent impacts on temperature, salinity and nutrient distributions that have far-reaching consequences for ocean dynamics and biogeochemistry, including climate-time-scale variability. The distribution of the energy in the internal tides is therefore a subject of considerable consequence. This project is focused on elucidating how, and how much, internal tide energy reaches the deep ocean. The investigators will undertake a set of numerical investigations to characterize and quantify the processes occurring when an upward-propagating, semi-diurnal, internal tide interacts with the variable stratification near the surface of the ocean and reflects back downward. The overarching question is "how much energy is 'lost' from the internal tide during its transits and reflection?"
Even though this loss of internal tide energy in the upper ocean has received little attention, it may result in a significant reduction in the amount of energy available to ocean mixing, which is critical for maintaining the stratification at depth, as well as the supply of nutrients for primary production near the surface. Proper representation of such processes in oceanic and climate numerical models continues to be a subject of intense research due to the sensitivity of these models to mixing distributions. . A graduate student, Ms. Sherry Chou, who has provided much material for the proposal resulting in this project, will continue her training in internal wave science and numerical modeling techniques, and will complete her dissertation. The numerical modeling results will also inform how best to apply oceanographic instrumentation to study intricate internal wave processes in the future.

The project's principal objectives are as follows: (1) To ascertain the range of the fluxes of energy from the internal tide into other phenomena (e.g., solitary waves; sub-harmonic waves; super-harmonic waves) as it interacts with the upper ocean stratification and free surface under different environmental conditions (such as different small-scale and large-scale stratification structures); and, (2) To explore from the numerical investigations how best to try to discriminate and quantify the different phenomena, which may all be present at once during the internal tide's transit through the real ocean, given the spatial and temporal sampling limitations of oceanographic instrumentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the great challenges of oceanography is to understand how solar heat that enters the upper ocean gets transported into the depths. Without mechanical mixing to facilitate downward heat transport, the ocean beneath a shallow wind-driven mixed layer would have a nearly uniform temperature just above freezing due to the sinking of cold water in the subpolar zones of the planet (heat input from undersea volcanoes is negligible). The great capacity of water to store heat, and thus mitigate somewhat the current warming of the atmosphere, can only be achieved if there are mechanical processes that mix the near-surface warm water deeper into the ocean. The major players producing this mixing, such as tides, and wind-driven currents and waves, are now known, but their relative contributions are not, and their variable production of mixing across the globe and through time are not at all well determined. 

       This project has attempted to put bounds on the broad question of how much mechanical energy is delivered to the deep ocean (below 1,000 meters) for mixing by “internal” tide waves. The surface tides, created by the gravitational pull of the moon and the sun on the oceans, ubiquitously draw sea level up and down along the coastlines of all land masses. Away from the coasts, their currents flow over the seafloor topography and push the interior of the ocean up and down, creating what are called “internal” waves. Internal tide waves have stronger currents than the surface tide and therefore are believed to produce a very large fraction of the turbulence and mixing needed in the deep ocean to bring upper ocean warmth downwards. 

       However, the internal tide waves created by the surface tide at seafloor topography propagate most of their mechanical energy upward before it’s harnessed for mixing. Near the surface, the internal tide waves interact with wind-driven currents and thermal fields and then reflect back downward. All of these interactions have the potential for extracting energy from the internal tides, but how much? And, which processes are most important and where? These are the broader questions that the current grant has been addressing.

       Using a suite of numerical models, backed by key observations, we’ve learned that the particular processes which extract energy from the internal tides at the surface, and their relative magnitudes, are highly dependent on the local environment, e.g., the latitude at which the internal tide interacts with the sea surface and the stratification of the upper ocean (that is, for example, how fast the surface temperature decreases with depth, which varies a lot over the globe; for example, consider tropical versus sub-polar thermal profiles). We’ve found that it’s not uncommon for the internal tide at a particular location to lose more than 50% of its energy during its transit from its source region up into the surface layer and back down, which has significant implications for how much energy is available for deep ocean mixing by the tides. The study has also revealed new pathways for energy from the surface tide into the deep ocean.

       The grant provided financial support and mentoring of a very promising graduate student, Ms. Sherry Chou, who will complete the requirements for the Ph.D. in Oceanography at the University of Hawaii in 2019.
